content.body:
[{"type": "rich_text", "value": "

This is a tutorial about one way to build and deploy a Wagtail CMS site to PythonAnywhere.

It's a starting point that has most of the elements one might need (backend and frontend) to build a Wagtail site and deploy it live. It's by no means a complete site, in fact I've intentionally left out a lot of the things that make a site unique, such as the design, content, and custom code so that you can use this as a starting point for your own site.

I recommend you read:

The official Wagtail documentation and Developer Documentation, specifically Your first wagtail site

I wanted to document the process I go through. I've actually built and deployed a fair few Wagtail sites over the last decade using various hosting platforms, as a freelancer. I now work for Torchbox as a developer.

  • \u2705 Python:3.10
  • \u2705 Mysql Database
  • \u2705 Node / webpack to build the frontend
  • \u2705 CI actions for code checks
  • \u2705 Pre-commit to run git hooks
  • \u2705 Wagtail CMS v5.1.1
  • \u2705 Django 4.1 (Mysql 5.7 requires Django < 4.2)

The code here is the complete source code after following the tutorial.

Part 2 - Has optional steps to add front end code, code quality checks and CI checks.

", "id": "d716dbed-7f85-4593-9232-2fa4388092dd"}, {"type": "callout", "value": "

Because I'm using git push to deploy the webapp and that requires SSH access, I am using a paid account on PythonAnywhere, which starts at \u20ac5/month.

", "id": "0d206651-7ee3-49fa-be07-c432c966b7cb"}]
content.title: Deploy Wagtail CMS to PythonAnywhere
content.excerpt: A guide to building a basic Wagtail CMS and deploying it to PythonAnywhere

content.body:
[{"type": "rich_text", "value": "

This is a tutorial about one way to build and deploy a Wagtail CMS site to PythonAnywhere.

It's a starting point that has most of the elements one might need (backend and frontend) to build a Wagtail site and deploy it live. It's by no means a complete site, in fact I've intentionally left out a lot of the things that make a site unique, such as the design, content, and custom code so that you can use this as a starting point for your own site.

I recommend you read:

The official Wagtail documentation and Developer Documentation, specifically Your first wagtail site

I wanted to document the process I go through. I've actually built and deployed a fair few Wagtail sites over the last decade using various hosting platforms, as a freelancer. I now work for Torchbox as a developer.

  • \u2705 Python:3.10
  • \u2705 Mysql Database
  • \u2705 Node / webpack to build the frontend
  • \u2705 CI actions for code checks
  • \u2705 Pre-commit to run git hooks
  • \u2705 Wagtail CMS v5.1.1
  • \u2705 Django 4.2

The code here is the complete source code after following the tutorial.

Part 2 - Has optional steps to add front end code, code quality checks and CI checks.

", "id": "d716dbed-7f85-4593-9232-2fa4388092dd"}, {"type": "callout", "value": "

Because I'm using git push to deploy the webapp and that requires SSH access, I am using a paid account on PythonAnywhere, which starts at \u20ac5/month.

", "id": "0d206651-7ee3-49fa-be07-c432c966b7cb"}]
content.title: Deploy Wagtail CMS to PythonAnywhere
content.excerpt: A guide to building a basic Wagtail CMS and deploying it to PythonAnywhere

fields.object_str: Initial repo and starting a new Wagtail project

content.body:
[{"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Create a new repo on your preferred provider. Github can add some files for you when starting a new project, I decided to add a README file and a gitignore file for Python.

Clone the newly created repo to your local development machine. It will have a remote called origin.

", "id": "a3d3f767-6c3f-47ae-aa47-f1e196d45d55"}, {"type": "callout", "value": "

Later on I'll create a remote called production which I'll use to deploy the site to PythonAnywhere.

", "id": "d3bafac7-3d27-4293-84f8-800dcde3ece7"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Python dependencies

There are a few ways to manage python dependencies, I'm using Pipenv but you can use your preferred method. The only caveat is that the production dependencies ideally need to be in a requirements.txt file when deploying to PythonAnywhere.

With Pipenv installed run:

", "id": "dabe2227-282f-4551-96d4-9799b9f73440"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "pipenv install "wagtail>=5.1,<5.2" "mysqlclient>=2.2,<2.3" "python-dotenv>=1.0,<1.1" "django>=4.2,<5.0"", "language": "bash"}, "id": "aaaaf3a3-fde2-4ed3-809f-02eb61989519"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Then create an initial requirements file with:

", "id": "0b2ce765-ae0a-4dda-8921-fdb6219b45a2"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "pipenv requirements > requirements.txt", "language": "bash"}, "id": "ebebc2c6-44a9-4514-9e83-d43422879065"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Start a Wagtail site

If you don't have one already, add a .gitignore file so we don't commit anything we shouldn't.

A good example of a python .gitignore file is https://github.com/github/gitignore/blob/main/Python.gitignore

The .gitignore file should also contain the following at this stage.

/media

Now create the initial Wagtail site called webapp or use your preferred name.

", "id": "6e4a9814-54b3-4f2f-844a-1a386b64fc7b"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "pipenv run wagtail start webapp", "language": "bash"}, "id": "bee4b813-919b-46ab-881b-9cfc8fbe8f09"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Modify the file and folder layout a little

", "id": "82d8c374-0f10-4465-aa89-25b799558f94"}, {"type": "callout", "value": "

I like to alter the layout of the files and folders a little to suit my preferences. It's not necessary but I find it easier to work with. You can skip this step if you prefer but make sure you adjust any paths in the following steps.

", "id": "a769e132-aedf-45f4-8134-383c654203db"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Inside the webapp directory you can delete the following files as they are not used on PythonAnywhere:

  • .dockerignore
  • Dockefile
  • requirements.txt
", "id": "446e29ec-2e34-4bde-a3c1-119b47a8cfe3"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "rm webapp/.dockerignore webapp/Dockerfile webapp/requirements.txt", "language": "bash"}, "id": "1e52eb8f-810e-4d59-9fcb-94178e201a9e"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Move the manage.py file to the root of the project:

", "id": "e8e66774-9343-4864-a8d5-5da96bbb5e72"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "mv webapp/manage.py .", "language": "bash"}, "id": "939fafb7-bb46-4171-9118-45109c42bd63"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Move the all the files and folders from the webapp/webapp directory up one level to the webapp directory:

", "id": "83d06159-e072-443d-bc42-091f93051ece"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "mv webapp/webapp/* webapp", "language": "bash"}, "id": "7da877a9-8758-465f-992b-f5a3e4266181"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Delete the empty webapp/webapp directory:

", "id": "55c1c87f-7ed2-4600-8082-ac0dd47d7f88"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "rm -rf webapp/webapp", "language": "bash"}, "id": "549d87c8-fe78-46ba-95fd-4026b91dc627"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Alter import paths and settings

Open webapp/urls.py and change the import path for:

", "id": "554f25d8-acce-4e09-8bc9-a702353d9a21"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "from search import views as search_views # to from webapp.search import views as search_views", "language": "python"}, "id": "ff16aeb4-1d06-4520-80ce-02331b449285"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Open webapp/settings/base.py and change the app names for home and search in INSTALLED_APPS to:

", "id": "b0389d29-7509-42c1-8985-8a55477da00a"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "INSTALLED_APPS = [ "webapp.home", "webapp.search", ... ]", "language": "python"}, "id": "a91cfbfb-5411-4356-bea2-2293c80ead1f"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

The project file structure should look like this:

.
├── venv
├── webapp
│ ├── home
│ ├── search
│ ├── settings
│ ├── static
│ ├── templates
│ ├── __init__.py
│ ├── urls.py
│ └── wsgi.py
├── .gitignore
├── manage.py
├── Pipfile
├── Pipfile.lock
├── README.md
├── requirements.txt

", "id": "02954837-c7c6-40d1-aa3c-f4188ffc24b2"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Run the Wagtail project locally

Run the Wagtail project locally to check that everything is working as expected, activate the virtual environment e.g. pipenv shell and run the following commands:

", "id": "41087582-e4d4-4488-85e2-ab3a7abc90ed"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "python manage.py migrate python manage.py createsuperuser", "language": "bash"}, "id": "f0b39fd3-9433-4c4d-bc3e-324048c329ba"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Then run the local development server:

", "id": "c5dd5815-4a17-45ce-a7ee-1174d505ac4e"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "python manage.py runserver", "language": "bash"}, "id": "916254e0-c8e1-4b63-97d1-d87c0aa1334d"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Open a browser and go to http://localhost:8000 and you should see the default Wagtail home page.

Open a browser and go to http://localhost:8000/admin/ and login with the superuser credentials you just created.

", "id": "3958791c-b6c4-419c-b511-ee64129c05f3"}, {"type": "callout", "value": "

The site is currently using sqlite3 database but later on it will be swapped out for a Mysql database.

", "id": "694b227d-a9d5-4f16-aac1-388b990a1513"}]
content.title: Initial repo and starting a new Wagtail project
content.draft_title: Initial repo and starting a new Wagtail project

content.body:
[{"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Setup environment variables

To handle the configuration of the Wagtail app to use mysql and later other settings I'll set up some environment variables.

Add a file to store the environment variables

", "id": "52b20549-481d-43f8-870e-74d1e2cd68ad"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "touch .env", "language": "bash"}, "id": "10ddfdd8-5a73-4198-9993-18e0db7f3046"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

and add the following content

", "id": "e7429ee7-29c3-4150-9b1f-c4ce5cd15f3c"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "MYSQL_ROOT_PASSWORD=webapp MYSQL_DATABASE=webapp MYSQL_USER=webapp MYSQL_PASSWORD=webapp MYSQL_ROOT_HOST='%' MYSQL_HOST=127.0.0.1 MYSQL_PORT=3306", "language": "bash"}, "id": "9a17ef1e-cd46-4387-9847-522c48c20ed6"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Although these variables aren't secret, later on we may add some that are and use it a template to create a .env file next.

To make sure the .env file doesn't get committed add the .env file to the .gitignore file:

", "id": "667a6590-07d3-47f8-933d-3d3e2c714bba"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "echo ".env" >> .gitignore", "language": "bash"}, "id": "39c53f44-4cb6-4cbf-a35a-3e071c69a316"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

These are development variables and to save having to set them every time I create a .env.example file to use as a template which can be committed to git (make sure there are no real secrets in this file). Then next time I need to set up for development I can just copy the .env.example file to .env and edit the values there.

", "id": "cc33a2ae-ad8f-463a-aaf7-7aaeff55cd46"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "cp .env .env.example", "language": "bash"}, "id": "35953bb9-5ef4-46cd-885e-95bbd5964074"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Add a mysql docker container for development

You will need docker installed to run the compose file: try Orbstack

This is a docker-compose setup that can be used to run up the Mysql database locally for development. If you already have Mysql running locally you can probably skip this step and use that instead.

Create a docker-compose.yml file in the root of the project and add the following content:

", "id": "1fee3dcb-7a5b-4fb1-8478-229244b82cb9"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "services: db: image: mysql:8.0.29 # version in use on pythonanywhere command: --default-authentication-plugin=mysql_native_password env_file: - .env ports: - "3306:3306" volumes: - dbdata:/var/lib/mysql container_name: mysql healthcheck: test: [ "CMD", "mysqladmin", "ping", "-h", "localhost" ] interval: 10s timeout: 20s retries: 5 adminer: image: adminer ports: - 8080:8080 depends_on: db: condition: service_healthy volumes: dbdata:", "language": "yaml"}, "id": "6ed2e237-bc63-463c-97cc-bd1df83bcd98"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Then from the root of your project run:

", "id": "bc27bea0-b544-43c3-80eb-1f9d6c00d720"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "docker-compose up -d", "language": "bash"}, "id": "b9b4f7c1-4d7e-4813-a990-40069e73ee94"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Because the .env file is available the running db container will use the MYSQL_... env vars. Therefore the username, password and database name are initialized to webapp

The adminer service is a web interface to the database.

To check the database is running, open a web browser and go to http://localhost:8080 and login with webapp as the username and password. You should see the database named webapp has been created.

Configure Wagtail to use the Mysql database

Open webapp/settings/base.py and find:

", "id": "81cd005c-33cf-4e41-a52f-6a8b48a22d4a"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "DATABASES = { "default": { "ENGINE": "django.db.backends.sqlite3", "NAME": os.path.join(BASE_DIR, "db.sqlite3"), } }", "language": "python"}, "id": "513c091e-94b2-4562-aa70-d75078e30a57"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

and replace it with:

", "id": "36eea068-6b4f-47be-80fd-0cef073fcdd4"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "DATABASES = { "default": { "ENGINE": "django.db.backends.mysql", "NAME": env_vars["MYSQL_DATABASE"] if "MYSQL_DATABASE" in env_vars else "", "USER": env_vars["MYSQL_USER"] if "MYSQL_USER" in env_vars else "", "PASSWORD": env_vars["MYSQL_PASSWORD"] if "MYSQL_PASSWORD" in env_vars else "", "HOST": env_vars["MYSQL_HOST"] if "MYSQL_HOST" in env_vars else "", "PORT": env_vars["MYSQL_PORT"] if "MYSQL_PORT" in env_vars else "", } }", "language": "python"}, "id": "f865e427-7ed7-494b-8b23-b034fe62d631"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Somewhere near the top of base.py add the following:

", "id": "ec4a144f-c34b-434c-9ea3-506d3c0da578"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "### existing code import os PROJECT_DIR = os.path.dirname(os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__))) BASE_DIR = os.path.dirname(PROJECT_DIR) ### end existing code env_vars = os.environ.copy() ### add this line", "language": "python"}, "id": "5564d4e1-5a13-4b5d-9809-778a3faa8136"}, {"type": "callout", "value": "

env_vars will hold all the environment variables and we can use them to connect to the local mysql database. In PythonAnywhere those environment variables will be available but that still needs to be setup.

", "id": "8d1b3b99-090d-4642-8cd9-35f56a0dc151"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Other Wagtail settings from environment variables

Still in base.py find and update the following lines:

", "id": "9e5c054e-93ec-4899-abda-afa4b0c65ff5"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "### existing code env_vars = os.environ.copy() ### end existing code ### add this code block if "DJANGO_SECRET_KEY" in env_vars: SECRET_KEY = env_vars["DJANGO_SECRET_KEY"] if "DJANGO_ALLOWED_HOSTS" in env_vars: ALLOWED_HOSTS = env_vars["DJANGO_ALLOWED_HOSTS"].split(",") ### Find WAGTAIL_SITE_NAME = "webapp" and change it to... WAGTAIL_SITE_NAME = env_vars["WAGTAIL_SITE_NAME"] if "WAGTAIL_SITE_NAME" in env_vars else "" ### WAGTAILADMIN_BASE_URL = "http://example.com" and change it to ... WAGTAILADMIN_BASE_URL = env_vars["BASE_URL"] if "BASE_URL" in env_vars else """, "language": "python"}, "id": "867664b2-80bf-46e3-a8e2-23c24be34e80"}, {"type": "callout", "value": "

When running in production, the environments variables will be loaded from that environment.

", "id": "3ddb5cfb-f8ff-40b9-b668-2010d7a0e61f"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Open your local .env file and add these new environment variables and alter the values, also make sure they are available in the .env.example file

", "id": "bda219eb-e65f-471e-ab01-1394148cb33b"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "WAGTAIL_SITE_NAME=site-name BASE_URL=http://localhost:8000 DJANGO_SECRET_KEY=not-so-secret_key DJANGO_ALLOWED_HOSTS=localhost", "language": "bash"}, "id": "e3c9e210-6534-4972-a41f-c297fd1006b8"}, {"type": "callout", "value": "

In local development they will be picked up by Pipenv and passed to the webapp when it's run.

Try out the webapp locally to make sure all is working OK.

Most of these settings will be overridden in dev.py when using runserver so probably won't make any difference.

", "id": "3c64dfa0-6c52-4b60-aa41-11b59c5e21d7"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Run the Wagtail project locally

Run the Wagtail project locally to check that everything is working as expected. With the virtual environment re-activated to load the environment variables e.g. `pipenv shell` and run the following commands:

", "id": "b9eb0fef-bf4a-40b7-8d73-722e26330467"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "python manage.py migrate python manage.py createsuperuser", "language": "bash"}, "id": "92fbf620-c838-470a-820c-041533668b78"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

and

", "id": "31c777c9-07ad-451e-82cf-c07798eff738"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "python manage.py runserver", "language": "bash"}, "id": "71c3e095-5ca0-4ef5-be78-518712380c3a"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Open a browser and go to http://localhost:8000 and you should see the default Wagtail home page.

Open a browser and go to http://localhost:8000/admin/ and login with the superuser credentials you just created.

", "id": "5639f392-7837-4a88-b6ea-8e5498253b3d"}]
content.title: Setup to use Mysql

content.body:
[{"type": "rich_text", "value": "

If you have content heavy pages in your Wagtail CMS and need to edit a piece of content after spotting a required change, it would be nice to be able to click a button next to the content and jump straight to it in the admin interface.

", "id": "76ec7179-bdf8-4cca-a5f9-0b1ec913842c"}, {"type": "callout", "value": "

It's similar to clicking 'edit this page' in the user bar but acts more like 'edit this content'

", "id": "3e6003cd-f9bf-44ef-afe8-5021b40da1da"}, {"type": "image_aligned_block", "value": {"image": 5, "alignment": "left", "content": "

Checkout the pencil icons

"}, "id": "d3025120-7968-474e-a40c-d0d6062f18fb"}]
content.title: Click to Edit Template Tags
content.excerpt: Add a click 2 edit icon to frontend templates. They behave like 'edit this page' but link to a field, section or streamfield content.

content.body:

If you have content heavy pages in your Wagtail CMS and need to edit a piece of content after spotting a required change, it would be nice to be able to click a button next to the content and jump straight to it in the admin interface.

", "id": "76ec7179-bdf8-4cca-a5f9-0b1ec913842c"}, {"type": "callout", "value": "

It's similar to clicking 'edit this page' in the user bar but acts more like 'edit this content'

", "id": "3e6003cd-f9bf-44ef-afe8-5021b40da1da"}, {"type": "image_aligned_block", "value": {"image": 5, "alignment": "center", "content": "

Checkout the pencil icons

"}, "id": "d3025120-7968-474e-a40c-d0d6062f18fb"}]

content.excerpt: Add a click 2 edit icon to frontend templates. They behave like 'edit this page' but link to a field, section or streamfield content.

content.body:
[{"type": "rich_text", "value": "

If you have content heavy pages in your Wagtail CMS and need to edit a piece of content after spotting a required change, it would be nice to be able to click a button next to the content and jump straight to it in the admin interface.

", "id": "76ec7179-bdf8-4cca-a5f9-0b1ec913842c"}, {"type": "callout", "value": "

It's similar to clicking 'edit this page' in the user bar but acts more like 'edit this content'

", "id": "3e6003cd-f9bf-44ef-afe8-5021b40da1da"}, {"type": "image_aligned_block", "value": {"image": 5, "alignment": "center", "content": "

Checkout the pencil icons

"}, "id": "d3025120-7968-474e-a40c-d0d6062f18fb"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

I've achieved this with a template tag (simple tag) that append an edit link to a piece of content. It can be a field, streamfield or section.

", "id": "e6dd2287-c03a-43b8-b2e1-83599ddfa8bf"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "from django import template from django.utils.safestring import mark_safe from django.conf import settings default_css_field = ( settings.C2E_CSS_FIELD if hasattr(settings, "C2E_CSS_FIELD") else "c2e-editable" ) default_css_section = ( settings.C2E_CSS_SECTION if hasattr(settings, "C2E_CSS_SECTION") else "c2e-editable" ) default_css_streamfield = ( settings.C2E_CSS_STREAMFIELD if hasattr(settings, "C2E_CSS_STREAMFIELD") else "c2e-editable absolute pull-up" ) svg_colors = ( settings.C2E_COLORS if hasattr(settings, "C2E_COLORS") else { "black": "#000000", "white": "#ffffff", "silver": "#c0c0c0", "red": "#ff0000", "green": "#00ff00", "blue": "#0000ff", "cyan": "#00ffff", "magenta": "#ff00ff", "yellow": "#ffff00", } ) default_svg_color = svg_colors.get("white") sizes = { "minature": 16, "small": 32, "medium": 48, "large": 64, } default_size = "small" default_relative_parent = "true" register = template.Library() def pencil_icon(color, size): return f"""""" @register.simple_tag(takes_context=True) def editable_field(context, value, id, field, **kwargs): if not context["request"].user.is_authenticated: return value color = kwargs.get("color", default_svg_color) size = kwargs.get("size", default_size) placement = kwargs.get("placement", "after") relative_parent = kwargs.get("relative_parent", default_relative_parent) classes = kwargs.get("classes", default_css_field) start_link = f"""""" link_content = f"""{pencil_icon(color, size)}""" end_link = "" button = start_link + link_content + end_link if placement == "after": return mark_safe(str(value) + button) return mark_safe(button + str(value)) @register.simple_tag(takes_context=True) def editable_section(context, section_name, id, **kwargs): if not context["request"].user.is_authenticated: return "" color = kwargs.get("color", default_svg_color) size = kwargs.get("size", default_size) relative_parent = kwargs.get("relative_parent", default_relative_parent) classes = kwargs.get("classes", default_css_field) start_link = f"""""" link_content = f"""{pencil_icon(color, size)}""" end_link = "" button = start_link + link_content + end_link return mark_safe(button) @register.simple_tag(takes_context=True) def editable_streamfield(context, value, id, **kwargs): if not context["request"].user.is_authenticated: return value color = kwargs.get("color", default_svg_color) size = kwargs.get("size", default_size) placement = kwargs.get("placement", "before") relative_parent = kwargs.get("relative_parent", default_relative_parent) classes = kwargs.get("classes", default_css_streamfield) ret = "" for block in value: link_start = f"""""" link_content = f"""{pencil_icon(color, size)}""" link_end = "" button = link_start + link_content + link_end if placement == "after": ret += str(block) + button else: ret += button + str(block) return mark_safe(str(ret))", "language": "python"}, "id": "bf70e0b3-f8bd-48e1-8a2b-63fbc12ec889"}]

content.title: Wagtail Exposapi
content.excerpt: A JSON API to expose your Wagtail sites internals

content.body:
[{"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Use this CLI: https://github.com/nickmoreton/wagtail-start to start a new Wagtail CMS site.

  • Remove the default welcome page
  • Add node and npm to the project
  • Add webpack to the project

It uses the Wagtail start command and then alters the sites folder and file layout. Optionally, you can also include a basic webpack setup to build and compile the front end code.

The site will include only a base home page and is ready for development.

Installation

", "id": "7ecc75e5-bcfa-45f0-9079-a729783903ac"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "poetry install", "language": "bash"}, "id": "0d27990e-acc5-4455-a02d-2f69930d422e"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Usage

", "id": "733f07a1-9416-4a54-aa94-755cb8c0f50c"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "poetry run new [project_name]", "language": "bash"}, "id": "a9cef8b8-506b-45f8-b435-8afeabbdc49e"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

The project will be created in it's own directory inside the parent directory of the CLI tool.

New site development

Once the site is generated, you can start developing it further.

Backend

Install the dependencies, use your preferred method of setting up a virtual environment.

Run

", "id": "9c6733a9-7ea3-4919-8c84-069d367927d2"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "python manage.py migrate\r\npython manage.py createsuperuser\r\npython manage.py runserver", "language": "bash"}, "id": "47bbfb2b-7ff1-40be-8724-5d9f67b4de13"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Frontend

  1. Install the dependencies: (nvm use if you have nvm installed) and npm install.
  2. Run the dev server: npm start.
  3. Open the site in your browser: http://localhost:3000.
  4. For production build: npm run build.
", "id": "9716eba7-6964-442c-86b9-1312399aea2b"}]

The site will include only a base home page and is ready for development.

Installation

Usage

The project will be created in it's own directory inside the parent directory of the CLI tool.

New site development

Once the site is generated, you can start developing it further.

Backend

Install the dependencies, use your preferred method of setting up a virtual environment.

Run

", "id": "9c6733a9-7ea3-4919-8c84-069d367927d2"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "python manage.py migrate\r\npython manage.py createsuperuser\r\npython manage.py runserver", "language": "bash"}, "id": "47bbfb2b-7ff1-40be-8724-5d9f67b4de13"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Frontend
